utterance: Why do you stop without orders from me?
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Them that understands our business knows it's customary to stop now and then for a pipe.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Your 'pipes' come often. It has not been a half-hour since you smoked and conferred together in some kind of a barbarous dialect. I am well enough versed in voyageur life to know that what is termed a pipe is not less than two hours.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: A feller that's all the way from Texas, and knows a little bit of everything, don't care to be catechized by a boy. I'm an old hand, I reckon, and know near about as much of the country as the next man. If I choose to take a dinner and a pipe ashore, I dare say there's nobody, old or young, can prevent me.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance:
You manifest a perverse and mutinous spirit, that well merits punishment; but I care not; on this occasion have your way.
But I warn you to put proper restraint upon your tongue and actions in future.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: You don't object to our lightin' a fire, I s'pose.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: It's against the rules of the service for the voyageur to put ashore for dinner; but, as I have said, in this instance do as you will.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Don't doubt that, mister!
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Their heads,
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I allow that somethin' warm won't do you no harm, youngster, notwithstandin' it's against the fashion to put ashore for dinner.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Villains!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: they have left me small chance of life. How can I battle with this piercing wind and this remorseless snow?
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I will not die!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I will not, I cannot be thus infamously cheated of existence ! Kind Providence, stretch out a hand to me in my need.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Remember me to-night, and I'll remember Thee forever.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Great Heaven!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance:
I shall now indeed be conquered.
But I will struggle manfully to the last.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Hullo, dog! what's the diffikilty?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Found a human critter, haven't ye?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I say, mister, this won't do! You'll get yourself into trouble in this way-you will, by thunder!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Go away!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: You annoy me.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance:
If I leave you, stranger, my name isn't Nick Whiffles. I never forsake a critter that's down with a condemned diffikilty.
Have got a medicine for you, I have. Wake ye up, I 'magine!
Will give ye the handsomest floggin' you've had since your old schoolmaster trussed you up for punishment. I will, I swear to gracious!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Make your bed on a perarie, will ye? Wrap yourself in a sheet of snow, and dream like a lazy Turk, won't ye? Will teach you better habits, if it costs consider'ble val'able time and the price of a ramrod. How do you like my treatment, stranger, eh?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: What-what do you mean, sir!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Mean to impose upon ye, you skunk,
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: There's a condemned little diffikilty between us, you see.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: The pain of death would have been less than the pain of resuscitation, but to you and your faithful dog I am, nevertheless, indebted for life.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Believe me, sir,
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I will remember the obligation.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance:
No doubt, stranger, no doubt! But don't trouble yourself about such trifles now. Take my arm and manage to walk as well as you can. I and my hoss was in the timber yonder, when I heerd the dog a-callin' me.
He didn't speak as you and I do; but he talked dog-talk plain enough. We know each other-he and I. He isn't prepossessin' in his out'ard natur, but he's powerful on the reasonin' fakilties.
You reel about summat, mister; but I'll have ye afore a warm fire in a minute, with somethin' stimulatin' in your stumach to put the cold blood in motion. I will, I swear to gracious !
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
Well, gal, you see I'm puttin' things in order for a start agin. It won't do for Old Saul to be idle long at a time.
He'd rust out in a little while.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: Do you know what I've been thinking of, my father?
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: How should I know, my pet, what passes through your little head in the course of a day, or a minute, for that matter? Somethin' whimsical, I dare say, and possibly without a particle of sense in it.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I have concluded,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: to go with the brigade.
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: When you have laughed enough, Saul Vander,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: we'll begin again, and see if we can get on together. I made a remark, I think.
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Yes, gal, you certainly made a remark !
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I'm goin' with the brigade !
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Talk on, Rosebud, I love to hear you; your voice to old Saul Vander, the Guide, is like the tinkling of silver bells.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: Guide-father, you shall hear it for the next year daily, or I'm no witch !
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: You're the greatest witch that ever was,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I've thought deeply on the subject,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: and have deliberately resolved to attend you through the vicissitudes of the next campaign. It is true I am young, and not greatly inured to hardship; but,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: I can do it-I know I can do it!
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Selkirk and the school-room for you, child. You'd break down the first day, gal, with the brigade.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: No, I wouldn't!
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Reflect a moment, darlin', on the dangers of a trapper's life,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: My pet guide,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: that is what I think of daily and nightly. I say to myself, when you are gone, 'Now my father is threading the dark defiles; or he is sitting by the lonely and perilous bivouac fires; or he is setting his traps in the dangerous haunts of the Blackfeet; or he may be at this moment wounded, with nobody to care for him.' Thoughts like these have often kept me restless.
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Rosebud,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I do believe you bear me much good will.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: Saul Vander
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: I assuredly have friendly feelings toward you. But
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: I shall go with the brigade.
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Saul Vander, how d'ye do? Nice day! Mornin' to ye, little one,
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
Hope I see ye! 'Low me to introduce to you a young feller that has a knowledge of everythin'
that he understan's, and is ign'ant of everythin' that he don't know nothin' about. His name is Kenneth Iverson, and you'll know him better when you git acquainted with him. Saul Vander, and you, Miss Sylveen, know my friend. I'm on rayther intimate terms with him; for once on a time, which was no longer ago than last winter, I give him the 'tarnalest hiding he ever had in his life. I did, I swear to gracious.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Mr. Iverson certainly comes to us highly recommended!
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: My friend Whiffles has undoubtedly rendered me an extraordinary service!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: It was this same ramrod that did the business,
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: When I'd done thrashin' him I's so weak that you could knocked me down with the small end of a feather.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: What had your friend
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: done to merit such discipline?
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance:
He was freezin', Miss! That's what he done.
The way on't was,
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: he was killed and left for dead, after which he was froze to death, and whipped into existence again by me. Chris Carrier and Jean Brand are the rogues that caused the diffikilty. I hope the time 'ill come, Saul Vander, when we can pay them off in their own coin. If I could once put Firebug on their track-Firebug is my hoss-backed up by Calamity, which is my dog, I wouldn't never stop till I'd made 'em acquainted with Humbug, which is my rifle.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: It appears to me,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: that you have rather queer notions about names. I can't see, for the life of me, the propriety of calling a rifle Humbug, for in reality there is less humbug about a rifle than anythin' you can mention.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance:
I reckon you'll allow there's some hum about it when it sends a ball six hundred yards through the mortal body of a redskin or an animile! We all have our pecoolyarities about certain things, and I have mine about names. I like to have some similarity in 'em, for it makes 'em easy to remember.
That dog
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
has had a number of names since I owned him, which has been ever since he's been a dog. You observe that he isn't an interestin' critter to look at, but he's a good feller at heart.
He's a little sour, I grant, in his dispersition, and is summat inclined to regard all the inhabitants of the airth as his natural enemies. He's a terror to evil-doers and the women-folks, and in fact to everybody else.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: A fine morning, Mr. Morrow,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance:
This is Nick Whiffles. Presume you've heerd of him more nor once.
This young man,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance:
is a friend of his'n
-Iverson his name is, I believe. Mister Iverson, Mark Morrow.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I think the morning air will not harm you, Miss Vander,
speaker: Mark Morrow

utterance: The morning air harms no one,
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance: Things go on pretty much to my mind,
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: My men will soon be on the way to the homes of the beaver and the haunts of the red man.
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: I heartily wish you success, and if experience does not go for naught, you will have it,
speaker: Mark Morrow

utterance: Better be quiet, mister! The odds is agin ye, and fightin' 'll prove a losin' game.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: Voyageurs, I did not expect the pleasure of your company. The joke is a tolerably good one. Take away your little instrument, friend Jean, and let us endeavor to understand each other
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: You'll understand us soon enough, I reckon.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: I never could quite comprehend the affair of Severn River. How you could leave a comrade to perish in the snow is to me a mystery. I have a vague idea, however, that we were attacked by Indians; that I received a blow upon my head that stunned me; and that you either made good your escape in the canoe, or were made prisoners.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: We can talk about them matters by-and-by, when we've nothin' else to do. Jean, keep your weapon at his head, while I tie his hands.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Villains! do you think I will tamely submit to be tethered like a goat?
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Moderately, my lad, what can't be bettered must be borne. If you want to have your brains knocked out on the spot, make a fuss and a bother, and it'll be done; but keep kind o' quiet like, and it may end better than you s'pect.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Put your hands behind you.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Now, you may get up; but don't try to run away. Jean, bring his horse.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: I insist upon knowing your intentions.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: We intend that you shall mount your horse and go with us as soon as he can be saddled and bridled. If you try to give us the slip, we'll shoot you as if you's a grizzly bear or a redskin !
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Fastened on in that kind o' style, I allow you won't be likely to fall off, even if you ain't a very good rider.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Stoop a little and come on; Jean, trudge at his heels.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: You can stand erect here.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Your journey isn't ended yet. Have patience, mister, and we'll show you what's known to few; and when you return to your friends agin, don't tell 'em the secret.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: It's extr'ordiner quiet-like for folks of a meditative turn o' mind, and I hope you'll like it well enough to stay with us a long time!
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: Hagar, stop your cacklin' and git us somethin' to eat ; we've got stomachs like wolves to-night.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: That chap takes it mighty easy. Don't think I could sleep in such a fix, no ways.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: Don't trust too much to appearances. The feller may be playin' possum. Take a chap like me, that's all the way from Texas, and he's naturally hard to be deceived, because he's seen enough of the world giner'ly to make him s'picious. It looks like real, that sleep does, but it may be only on the surface, for all that.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: What's the cap'n mean to do now?
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: Nothin' good, I'll warrant. We'll keep him safe and snug till further orders; though, if I had my way, I'd- On account of what happened when we undertook to paddle him from York Factory to Norway House, it'll be a great deal safer for us to have him out of the way, you know. Some furrin country will agree with him better nor this.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: He's rather tough in his constitution, and hard to rub out; if he hadn't been, he'd never revived after we left him, and lived through the bitter night that follered. Howsumever, I don't greatly mind his gittin' over it, and as for the cap'n's affairs, he must look out for 'em as he sees best.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: It were a crime to send such ruffians into the other world.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: There he is clingin' like a tree-toad to the bark of a tree. I'll bring him down as they bark squirrels in Texas!
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: That dark shadder is nothin' more nor a rift in the ledge. I've noticed it often when I come home late o' nights.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: We'll see about that, I allow. Come down from that, youngster, or I'll fire and give you a tumble that won't be over an' above safe for your bones.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: I've missed him, Jean; give me your rifle.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: No, you're too drunk to shoot. If there's anything there, I'll fetch it myself.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: You can't hit the cliff itself!
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Mister, I allow you'd better listen to reason and come down. A fall from that distance won't leave you in a shape to be recognized by your friends. As for settin' on your body arter such a tumble, it wouldn't be possible for a coroner to do it.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: He moves, he moves.
speaker: Jean Brand

utterance: It's a rift in the rock, is it, you stupid mule! Whoever heard of a rift climbing in that way?
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Mister, I allow you'd better listen to reason 59 and come down. A fall from that distance won't leave you in a shape to be recognized by your friends. As for settin' on your body arter such a tumble, it wouldn't be possible for a coroner to do it.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: I warn you that I'll shoot.
speaker: Chris Carrier

utterance: Ruffian! if your aim proves fatal, you shall not have the pleasure of seeing me fall, at least. If I die in this narrow niche, it shall be my sepulcher.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Cold-blooded miscreant! you are baffled again.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Faithful companion of man! do not thou, at least, forsake me!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Come! what you 'bout there?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Hain't got into no diffikilty, have ye? Makin' a confounded fuss up there, seems to me. Git up, Firebug; let's see what the trouble is.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Thought I heerd a voice! What does it all mean, I wonder? Hullo! Anybody in diffikilty hereabouts?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: It is I-Kenneth Iverson!
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Beavers and otters! What made you locate in sich an ungreeable place as this?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: You shall know all about it, my friend, after you get me out.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: But I can't git you out-I can't, I swear to gracious! The devil himself couldn't git you out. It's a cussed little diffikilty that'll be hard gittin' over!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I shall trust to your own ingenuity.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Ingenuity, indeed! All I can do is to give you my blessin' and leave ye. If you've got any word to send to your friends, I'll take it along with me. However, I'll go down below, and see how it looks in that direction, pervidin' there's any way of gittin' there.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I feel as safe as if I was out already.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Then you feel a condemned sight better about it nor I do, for I'll be shot if it isn't the tightest place that I ever see a critter in Come, 'Calamity,' find me the way down to the lake, 'thout breakin' my neck.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: One moment.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Look out for Chris Carrier and Jean Brand; you may encounter them below.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Oh, they've had a hand in it, have they? I'll play the mischief with them mean skunks yet. I will, by the Lord! Why, this is worse than freezin' to death! Stay where you be, will ye, till I git round?
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I think I shall.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Foller me, and I'll show you a better way nor that up the side of the rock. Calamity led me down like a major, by a way I never should have found alone, though it was a long way round, and I was obleeged to scramble right smart sometimes, and hold tight whatever I could reach. Take a drop from my flask, man, for you look pale as a ghost. This was rayther a dizzy place to settle in, but when my gran'father was makin' the tower of the world he was often in worse predicaments nor that. He allers traveled in a one-horse sulky, did my gran'father, with the top turned back, so that he could see all that was to be seen. Well, one day he drove up Mount Vesuvius, jest to divart his mind, and give his hoss, which had been stannin' in the stable a good 'eal of late, a little exercise.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Isn't that rather a novel method of ascending Moun Vesuvius?
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Bless your simplicity, no. It was very common in the time o' my gran'father. As I was sayin', he drove up in his sulky, and it bein' Sunday, the institution was putty quiet. It happened, as my uncle was drivin' round the crater-
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Grandfather.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I said gran'father. As my gran'father was drivin' round the crater, one wheel went over, and he fell into the consarn neck an' heels, though fortinitly for the world, he left his manuscripts, nick-nacks, and rare specimens in the sulky, which recovered its equalabraham the minute my gran'father was slopped out. Well, my gran'father fell nigh to a hundered feet, off an' on, 'cording to his best calkilations.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: He was injured a good deal, I suppose?
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Not a tall. He fell into a bed o' warm ashes, and didn't feel the shock none to speak on; though it raised sunthin' of a dust, which prevented him from ever writin' a detailed description of the 'pearance of things inside. He didn't go to the bottom by a long sight. It was so deep that you might look two days upon the stretch an' never see the end on't. It was my gran'father's opinion that it had once been inhabited by pirates; but how they got in an'-
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: ker's all gone, I swear to gracious!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: My name is not Hammet, but Iverson, and I happen to be the uncle of this young man; but a relative that he has not seen since he was a mere boy. I accumulated wealth as a partner of Hudson's Bay Company. I am not now in the great Northwest. I traversed this country years ago, hence my knowledge of its vicissitudes and peculiarities. You have often wondered, no doubt, at the confidence with which I went abroad and intrusted myself in places of peril; that confidence was the legitimate outgrowth of experience. Having acquired a fortune in the fur trade, I returned to England where I was born. Your father, as you know, died when you were a child, leaving you an orphan, for your mother died in giving you birth. You were confided to the care of an uncle on your mother's side, who, dying before you were of age, left his fortune to you, on condition that you should marry his only daughter, in order to keep the property in the family.
speaker: Abram Hammet

utterance:
And that match I declined, which refusal turned me adrift to seek my own fortune. That affair has been a source of much unhappiness; but the joy of to-day compensates all.
If the girl had been handsome, agreeable, and lovable, I never should have seen Hudson's Bay, Red River, and,
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: Sylveen Vander.
speaker: Kenneth

utterance: I allow you's pooty near right not to marry a gal you didn't like. I wouldn't marry a gal, if she's made o' gold, pervidin' she didn't just take possession of my in'ard natur by storm. I wouldn't, by thunder!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: The Blue-Robed Cloud has done that, I reckon?
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance:
The Whiffles family never struggle ag'in destiny. What's to be will be, and they know it.
He is a fool that holds back ag'in fatality. I knowed that these two would come together, soon's never I see 'em clap their eyes on each other. Take good care of Rosebud, cap'n; take good care on her. She'll make you happy.
She'll make you happy. O Lord, yes!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
I had no heirs in England, so I naturally fell to thinking of the bright little boy I had seen in Kentucky years before. Well, thinking produces action, and, in this case, it resulted in a voyage to America. When I reached your birth-place, you had gone, on account of your uncle's unlucky will, and the persecution and bitterness.
growing out of it. I traced you to Montreal, and discovered there, from an agent, that you had gone into the service of the Hudson's Bay Company. It was easy enough then to follow.
you. I joined a small party and reached Red River, in due time, by the great lakes. At Selkirk I heard of your duel with Mark Morrow, and the departure of the trapping brigade, of which this young woman formed an interesting, if not an efficient fraction. Connecting all the circumstances, I naturally concluded that you would be found not a great way from that notable company of trappers. I was on the trail of the brigade, when I happily fell in with you and your eccentric friend, Nick Whiffles. Wishing to test your character, while I disguised my own, I assumed the Quaker garb and idiom, which I have sustained more or less creditably, as you may happen to think.
speaker: Abram Hammet

utterance: Which is the sin of deception than which nothing more vile and abominable. O-h, a-h!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I often excited your curiosity and suspicion, and not unfrequently the resentment of Nick Whiffles. I confess, I sometimes took pleasure in annoying and mystifying your friend. In me, of course, you behold the 'secret slayer.' I slew our enemies in the easiest manner, and in the stealthiest way possible, in order to keep up my assumed character; also to set the tongue of gossip and conjecture in motion, in which particular you must acknowledge I succeeded. I was both amused and gratified at the manner in which this inexplicable subject was treated by yourself and friends. I have a strong arm, you observe; a single blow with this hatchet put the unlucky redskin who came in my way out of pain and the consciousness of dying. On the whole, it was a merciful method, and since none but the deserving of such a fate suffered, I am sure you will not accuse me of cruelty, or the needless shedding of blood.
speaker: Abram Hammet

utterance:
That makes everythin' straight, and, seein'
that them that went under in that shape was our enemies, we, of all people, ought to be the last to find fault. I used to talk ruther hard to you sometimes, Broadbrim, which I hope you'll be magnanimous enough to forgit and forgive. You're a fine feller, and anybody that says to the contrary will git into a condemned diffikilty!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
If there's anythin' that'll revive him, it's the sound of your voice, Rosebud! Did you see him prick up his ears? And there's a wavy motion of his tail, too. It's been a dog's age since he wagged his tail afore.
It's refreshin' to see him look so nateral and sprightly-like, for you must know, Rosebud, that it's a terrible sick of fitness 409 that he's had. It took the animosity out of him dreadful, but he follered your trail till he tumbled down from sheer weakness. He knowed where you'd trailed, Miss, and that we wanted to find ye.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
You all seem to be in good sperits, but I can't help thinkin' o' my losses, I vow. Sich a beeverage as that was! Red River water, fifty per cent. alcohol and aqua fortis ! I'll take the law on them pison sarpents.
I'll be skinned if I don't!
speaker: Goliah Stout

utterance:
There's my horse, by gracious! I'll prove property and pay damages. There's a keg on one side, and a drunken Injin on t'other.
Git off'm his back, you pison sarpent!
speaker: Goliah Stout

utterance:
I'm the dividin' line-the great unmated terror of the North! As for this hoss, you're welcome to him, for such an old bench isn't fit for the Raven of Red River to perch on. I ruther paddle a 'tarnal mud-scow with my hands than try to propel sich an animile. Ned Wraggles, how are ye? Thought you's dead, old boy! How's your catamounting? Was on his last leg when I saw him, and that was bendin' like the mischief. Looks a plaguey sight better, don't he? Never liked me very well, and I don't know of anybody that does. Dividin' lines don't seem to be very pop'lar. That dog'll live to be a comfort to ye yet, Wriggles.
You stuck to him like a burr. There isn't many fellers that'd resk their lives for a quadruped, but I respect you for it, Wraggles. Now, if anybody hasn't no objections, I'll git some o' the surplus caw out of me.
speaker: Tom Slocomb

utterance: The happiness of these two creturs reminds me of the days of my own youthful folly, when that unfeelin' man stole away my virgin affections and primeval purity, which might have remained, if I had the experience that I now have, and knowed what matrimony is as well as I do this day.
speaker: Perscilla Jane

utterance:
The Wolf has bitten ! He has tasted the blood of his enemy. Fox-Foot will never see the sun rise again. He said he would drown me while I was young. The knife that he gave me was concealed in my bosom. I wrenched my hands free before they threw me over. Before I reached the bottom of the lake, I cut myself free from the stone.
I swam under water a long distance, when, rising cautiously to the surface, I made my way silently to the shore. I have watched him-I have thwarted him-I have had my revenge!
Sunrise, he is gone to the hunting-grounds of the white man.
This hand sent him there!
speaker: Le Loup

utterance: Is he indeed dead?
speaker: Sylveen Vander

utterance:
The Master of Life has called him. You will see him no more. His body lies in yonder valley.
To-night the wolves will feast upon him. Already the birds of prey are circling over him. Sunrise, look yonder!
Behold that smoke rising 411 from the distant hills; a party of my people are there. I go to join them. Girl of the sunrise eyes, here we part! I have loved you, but the Great Spirit has willed that I should love you no more. The Wolf has worshiped in secret; he has kissed your shadow; he has licked the dust where you have been the light of his soul.
Sunrise, beautiful Sunrise, farewell! We shall meet in the land of souls!
speaker: Le Loup

utterance: So Mark's gone, and Chris too! That makes two of the mean skunks disposed of. Jean Brand oughter jine that party. We should make him confess, leastwise.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
I thought o' that, and told him he might as well make a clean breast on't while I's drubbin' him.
He improved the hint, and let out some things that'll prove ruther interestin'. He's the chap that run off with the gal that we found by the lake. A deal o' trouble he caused her, as we know by the plight she was in when we took her on the raft.
speaker: Tom Slocomb

utterance: I made some inquiries at the fort respecting your pretty waif, and learned that she was the daughter of an old friend, formerly a partner in the Hudson Bay Company. I shall take it upon me to look after her welfare.
speaker: Abram Hammet

utterance: Hand me up that dog.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I don't see how you're goin' to carry that dog, you understand?
speaker: Saul Vander

utterance: The man that found a way to take keer of him when the pesky heathen was throngin' upon us four to one, can also find a way to carry him when there's a hoss to help.
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: All ready? Let the procession start!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: See the conquering hero comes !
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance:
We must rise above 'em. We're doin' very well, now. There's a right smart prospect of a weddin'. There was a good many weddin's in the Whiffles family. Most all of 'em jined one way and another. But marriage isn't allers the end of airthly troubles.
O Lord, no; weddin's sometimes lead to the condemnest diffikilties!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: Take good care of her, lad; take good care of Rosebud ! Don't never make her sorry that she took a likin' to ye. Don't never let me see her in a diffikilty of your makin'. If I do, I'll call you to an account for it!
speaker: Nick Whiffles

utterance: I will, by mighty !
speaker: Nick Whiffles
